MEANING: 1 feast 2 horse-race 3 a prize in horse-race
RUSMEAN: 1 праздник 2 скачки 3 приз за победу в скачках
REFERENCE: VEWT 54, 56, ЭСТЯ 2, 32, 33-34 (erroneously under *baδrak 'flag'), 35-36, TMN 2, 384-385. Here one should reconstruct *-j- (not *-δ-), dissimilated before -r- according to Mudrak's rule. Formally *baj-ra-m and *baj-ra-k are deverbatives from a hypothetical *baj-ra- 'to celebrate'; *baj-ga is a denominative with a usual East.-Kypch. suffix. Menges' (1933, 101) hypothesis of bajga < Russ. is quite unlikely (cf. the areal and the Chag. fixation). A rather popular theory of Iranian origin is also excluded: the only acceptable etymology of Pers. bajram is < Turkic (see also ЭСТЯ). Because of semantics, hardly connected with Mong. baj 'sign, goal, road sign'. Turk. > Russ. Siber. bajgá (Аникин 109).
EDT 384, 385, VEWT 56, ЭСТЯ 2, 30-32, Лексика 83. The Chuvash form is difficult.
EDT 311, VEWT 58, ЭСТЯ 2, 38-40, Мудрак 99, Stachowski 70.

EDT 356, VEWT 84, TMN 2, 333, ЭСТЯ 2, 219-221, Лексика 160, Stachowski 63. Аникин 128-129)). See also Abaev 1, 263 (isn't the East Iranian form itself < Turkic?)

EDT 362, VEWT 84, TMN 2, 289, ЭСТЯ 2, 221-223, Лексика 482, Stachowski 58. In Tuva, Tof.  *-rk > rt  is regular. Reconstruction of length is not quite certain: Turkm. length is not confirmed by Khalaj and contradicts pharyngealization in Tofalar.  Turk. > WMong. bürgü, Kalm. bürgə (KW 67), Khalkha bürx (although theoretically this may as well be an indigenous derivative of  bürü-, cf. similar Turkic forms: Tur. dial.  bür-me, bür-gü 'headgear').
VEWT 78, ЭСТЯ 2, 169, Stachowski 67. Turk. > WMong. boɣus, Kalm. bōs (KW 54), Dag. bōs (Tod. 127), see Clark 1980, 39.

EDT 704, VEWT 246-247, ЭСТЯ 5, 23-24, Stachowski 144, 146. Forms like Yak. ketex 'back of head' clearly show that the root was *ged-; the monosyllabic *ge- (observable in Yak. ke-lin and perhaps Chuv. kaj) is most probably a result of secondary reinterpretation of the stems *gedin and *gerü (the latter < PA *kèro q.v.). It is exactly this reinterpretation that allows to reconstruct *g- in PT *ged- (the root is not attested in Oghuz languages).

The word has an anatomical meaning ('hip') in old sources, but the meaning 'side' is also attested and must be more archaic, to judge from external evidence; the more abstract meaning in Chuvash ('vicinity') also supports 'side' as the original meaning.

EDT 872, VEWT 202, ЭСТЯ 4, 196-197. Except Uzb., Uygh., Chuv. and possibly Yak. all languages actually reflect  *jẹp- (*jip-); the Inlaut stop may be a result of secondary gemination, or reflect a merger with some other root. Original voiced *-b- ( > -v-), however, is well preserved in the derivative *jẹbiĺ(č) 'wet' (Karaim jüvüš, Tat. jüwiš,  Bashk. jĭvĭš). Turk. > Kalm. ǯī- 'durchnäßt werden' (KW 114; although phonology is somewhat strange: one would rather expect Kalm. ǯiw-).

The words for 'front' and 'colour, face' are usually treated as different roots (e.g. in EDT, ЭСТЯ), but it is hardly possible to separate them phonetically (the variants \I*oŋ\i and *öŋ do not seem to be semantically distributed); the semantic shifts (*'front' > 'face' > 'colour') are quite natural.

VEWT 241, ЭСТЯ 5, 335-336, TMN 3, 419, Stachowski 140, Ашм. XVI, 250-255, Федотов 2, 371-372. The original meaning must have been one of two layers" - as witnessed by the Yak. meaning and by external evidence."

VEWT 242, ЭСТЯ 5, 339-340, TMN 3, N\Ho\h 1395. The Turkic form may well be borrowed < Iran., cf. Saka  khaḍara- 'mule'. Here -ḍ- points to *rd, cf. Sogd. ɣrtr'k < *xarataraka 'mule' (for a quite similar compound cf. Pers. astar 'mule' < *assa-tara 'horse from one side'(Bailey 70). Doerfer is concerned about lack of length in Turkic, but length is likewise lacking in Saka and other Iranian forms. The only phonetic difficulty is the Turkic reflex -t-, because Saka ḍ in the Saka-Uygh. glossary (14th c.) renders Turkic -r-. In one obvious  Saka loan the Saka -ḍ- is indeed rendered as -r-:  cūḍāṃ 'stadium' (Av. čarətu-)  >  OT (Hap. by MK) čurām 'a shot with a light far-flying arrow. However, if 'mule' is borrowed, it is hardly a Xinjiang loanword but rather a Common Turkic, and perhaps from another Iranian language (Sogdian?).

EDT 938, VEWT 201, ЭСТЯ 4, 252-253, Stachowski 118. The deriving stem *jɨm-ĺča- 'to be soft' is also present in most of the above languages.

On the other hand, cf. the common Turkic derivative *jal-ta-, perhaps reflected in the above Yak. form, as well as in Turkm. jalta, Shor čaltak, Khak. čaltɨ 'lazy', Tur. jaltak 'bootlicker' etc. (see ЭСТЯ 4, 101-102).

VEWT 184, EDT 942, ЭСТЯ 4, 114, Лексика 564. Turk. > WMong. ǯanu-, Kalm. zan- (KW 466). The Turkm. form is related to *jenč- 'crush' in ЭСТЯ 185; the latter has also a variant *janč-, and the Turkm. form may in fact reflect a contamination of these two roots.
EDT 120-121, TMN 2, 94-95, ЭСТЯ 1, 125-126. A loanword in Russ. \Iалый.\i

MEANING: 1 to crush, destroy 2 to curse, reproach
REFERENCE: EDT 937, VEWT 197, ЭСТЯ 4, 183-184, Егоров 210. The meaning 'crush, destroy, widespread in modern languages, must be a secondary development from the original more abstract 'harm' (whence also 'curse, reproach').

MEANING: 1 to tune (an instrument) 2 to recuperate 3 to remedy
REFERENCE: EDT 179, 182, Егоров 64, Мудрак 135. Федотов 1, 153 compares the Chuv. form with OT oŋar- 'to correct', which is phonetically worse.

EDT 60, ЭСТЯ 1, 202-203. Turk. > WMong. atan 'castrated camel'. Cf. also Yak. \Iat\i 'castrated', attā- 'to castrate' - homonymous with \Iat\i 'horse', which is probably a secondary merger (the two roots obviously are to be kept separate).
VEWT 467. Cf. Khalkha tataj 'an interjection of hate, loathe', perhaps originally < Turkic; the Mong. form = Khak., Oyr., Yak., Kirgh. tataj, Tuva dadaj.

Räsänen (Рясянен 1955, 134) derives the forms from tak- 'to adhere', but vowel length clearly contradicts it. Quite dubious, because of geographic distribution, is the derivation of the word from Greek τήγανον 'frying pan' (see Аникин 521-522). The Greek word itself has no satisfactory etymology (see Frisk 2, 845).

VEWT 475-476, EDT 544, TMN 2, 499-500. The stem is connected - in a somewhat unclear fashion - with *tirke- 'to hitch' (derived from tiz- 'to string' in Хелимский 1986 and Дыбо 1995, 282 - but the latter should be properly reconstructed as *diŕ-, so this derivation is by no means certain). External evidence suggests that *-i- is original here; the vowel *-e- in *terkü may be due to the influence of *dēr-ke- 'to gather; equip' (see *dēr-).

REFERENCE: VEWT 482, Лексика 115, 121. The Siberian forms clearly point to *-b- (or *-g-); other forms have been influenced by \I*top\i and \I*dom-\i / \I*tom-\i 'round' q. v. sub *t`òp`ú , *t`ŏ̀mù. Turk. > Mong. (Kalm.) toburčag 'acorn, cone' (KW 404); see Poppe 47.

VEWT 485, TMN 2, 524, EDT 469, Лексика 434, Stachowski 229. Turk. > Hung. toklyó 'lamb', see Gombocz 1912.

RUSMEAN: 1 волосок, струна, проволока 2 ремешок, которым привязан наконечник стрелы 3 прядь, пучок нитей
REFERENCE: VEWT 471, EDT 491. Turk. > NPers., Kurd., Osset. tel etc. Bailey 129 cites Saka ttīla 'thread, wire' and considers it the source of Turkic forms, tracing it back to *tarϑrya - cf. Pers. tār < *tarϑra. However there are no direct Iranian parallels for the Saka form (cf. Аб. 3, 288, maintaining that the Osset. and Kurd. form do not go back to Proto-Iranian but are borrowed from neighbouring languages); so the word may well be a Turkism in Saka and other Iranian languages. The Turkic origin is also corroborated by the Chuv. parallel.
VEWT 475, Федотов 2, 236-237 (the meaning `judge, discriminate' cannot be explained from Arab. terk `leave').
VEWT 495, EDT 533.

REFERENCE: VEWT 365-366, EDT 247, 248, ЭСТЯ 1, 479-481, 608 (distinguishes osal and usan- - but the narrowing osan- > usan- is a local Oghuz phenomenon and probably secondary, due to interdialectal loans), Егоров 277, Федотов 2, 290. Turk. > Mong. osal (MMong. (SH) osolda-), see TMN 2, 149, Clark 1980, 39, not vice versa - despite Щербак 1997, 207.

column38: is very well attested (often in the shape *otagu) and certainly containing a short vowel."

REFERENCE: VEWT 367, ЭСТЯ 1, 487-488. Usually derived from \I*ot\i 'grass'  but the morphological pattern is unclear; the word might well be archaic despite lack of ancient attestation. Cf. also Balkan words like Hung. határ etc., most probably of Turkic origin. Turk. > WMong. otar, Kalm. otr (KW 291).
EDT 334, VEWT 74, ЭСТЯ 2, 139-140, Лексика 71, Stachowski 70.
ЭСТЯ 1, 582, ДТС 608.

VEWT 338, Егоров 78, Федотов 1, 194, Дмитриева 189, Лексика 126. The word is attested late (like many tree names), but borrowing from Russ. ильм is hardly possible; the Russian word, usually considered a Germanism (MHG ilme etc.), may equally well be explained as a Turkism (see Егоров ibid.). The resemblance of PT *ilme and PIE *l̥mo- / *olmo- is interesting, but probably accidental (if the Turkic word indeed goes back to PA *p`i̯ule.

REFERENCE: ЭСТЯ 1, 137-138, EDT 137-138, Егоров 343, Stachowski 31, Мудрак Дисс. 181 (regarding the Yak. form as borrowed < Tuva because of its vocalism).
ЭСТЯ 1, 538.
EDT 170-171, ЭСТЯ 1, 537-538, VEWT 372 ( > Kalm. öŋgɛ̄n, KW 297).

EDT 317-318, ЭСТЯ 2, 235-238, Лексика 152, Лексика 446-447, Stachowski 67. Turk. bugura > Mong. buɣura (see TMN 2, 296, Щербак 1997, 110). Щербак 1997, 201 considers Turkic *bugu to be borrowed from Mongolian buɣu 'male deer' (which may be true for some Kypchak forms: Kirgh. buɣu, Kaz. bŭɣɨ, Nogh., KKalp. buɣɨ), but in fact one can also think of a loan in the opposite direction: Turk. > Mong. buɣu (KW 58, MGCD 166), further > Evk. buɣu etc., see Doerfer MT 78. Turk. > Russ. Siber.  burá 'female camel';  Mong. (Bur.) būra > Russ. Siber. búra id., see Аникин 142.

MEANING: a stone pillar erected on a grave
REFERENCE: EDT 333. Borrowed (possibly from an unattested Bulgar source) in Old Russ. bolvanъ, Hung. bálvány 'stone idol' (suggestion of Melioranski, evidently preferable to the hypothesis of Korsch-Dmitriev < Pers. pahlavān, see Шипова 84-85, Аникин 114).

MEANING: 1 to knock (down), hit, agitate 2 to whet 3 to slaughter 4 to mow 5 scythe 6 to sting, pierce 7 to sweep 8 to chop 9 a k. of broom 10 to sharpen, whet 11 whetstone 12 mowing, hay time 13 to trip 14 blade
RUSMEAN: 1 сбивать, ударять, бить, взбалтывать 2 точить 3 убивать, закалывать 4 косить 5 коса 6 жалить, закалывать 7 подметать 8 изрубить, отрубить 9 вид метлы, веник-голик 10 точить 11 оселок 12 покос 13 дать подножку 14 острие, лезвие
REFERENCE: VEWT 97, EDT 417-418 , Егоров 206, Федотов 2, 132, 133. The difference in length between Turkm. and Yak. allows to suppose a merger of at least two roots, perhaps originally distinguished semantically and phonetically as *čāl- 'to knock down' (reflected in Yak., not reflected in Turkm.) - *čal- 'to sharpen, whet' (reflected in Turkm., not reflected in Yak.). Since Verba des Schlagens" are generally  vague semantically
column36: in most languages it is difficult to draw a line between them."

REFERENCE: VEWT 210, ЭСТЯ 4, 247-248, Лексика 165-166. Turk. > Mong. ǯurum, ǯurama, Khalkha ʒuram, ʒurma, Dag. ǯombor, (Tod. 145) ǯumbrā (see MGCD 464, KW 481, TMN 4, 220), whence Man. ǯumara etc., see Doerfer MT 102, Rozycki 127. Cf. also *jamlan / *jalman (VEWT 183, ЭСТЯ 4, 97; > Mong. jalman). Turk. > Russ. dial. jevrán and similar forms, see Аникин 195, 199, 205.

RUSMEAN: 1 гвоздь, колышек, чека 2 угол 3 penis 4 хвойное дерево
UIG: čüä 3 (R, by animals), čivä 'space between legs above the knees', čivilän 'back saddlegirth' (fixed with a wooden peg)
REFERENCE: VEWT 110, 121, EDT 393-394, 396, Лексика 125, 398. Because of well known semantic correlations of the type 'penis': 'thorn': 'fir (needle)' it is tempting to compare also the name of the fir-tree: Tat. dial. (КСТТ) čivi, cɨvɨ, Khak. sɨbɨ, Shor šübe, Oyr. čibi (Tuba čɨbɨ),  Tuva šivi, Tof. šibi. However, the intermediate form meaning 'thorn' is not attested, and the medial consonant here is rather *-p- (unless we suppose interdialectal loans), so it may be unrelated.
Дыбо 171. It is also necessary to note Kaz. šege, Kirgh. čege 'nail', possibly going back to the same root.

VEWT 424, EDT 857, ДТС 524 , Егоров 341, Федотов 2, 467, Stachowski 128-129. Languages display both assimilations and dissimilations (loss) of the first consonant. Loss of length in Yak., Tuva and Tof. is not quite clear (Turkm. clearly demonstrates a long -ī-); if we take into account the Chuv. reflex (-ɨ- corresponding to Common Turkic i/ɨ), we should perhaps reconstruct a PT form *sɨ̆jĺč- (see Мудрак Дисс. 158).

REFERENCE: EDT 417, VEWT 96, TMN 2, 31, Аникин 640. Turk. > WMong. čal, Kalm. cal, Khalkha cal būral 'grey-haired, roan'; Russ. \Iчалый.\i
R 4, 336-337, VEWT 403 (suggesting a derivation from sar-, saru- 'to tie round' - which is also not excluded).
VEWT 118-119. Note however that most of the forms listed in VEWT actually reflect PT *čopur (v. sub *šop`é), so the root *čubar appears to be very late and local.
EDT 846, VEWT 419, ЭСТЯ 7.

(SH) saɣal, WMong. saqal, Kalm. saxəl, KW 308;  > Hung. szakál, see Gombocz 1912; Mong. > Evk. sakal etc., see Doerfer MT 100).

EDT 5, ЭСТЯ 1, 158-159, ССЯ 290-291, Лексика 300, 301, TMN 2, 3, Аникин 90. Front row variants (Tur. eve, Kaz. ebej, Yak., Dolg. ebe etc., see ЭСТЯ 1, 220-221, Stachowski 42) are recent and may have a Mong. origin.
EDT 4, 8-9, VEWT 34, Егоров 19 (Федотов 1, 25-26 - differently).

ЭСТЯ 1, 237-241, TMN 2, 176, EDT 41, Лексика 324-325, Stachowski 122. Some forms (Tur. ɨs, is, Yak. ičči etc.) go back to a suffixed *ede-si; the Khak. and Shor forms should be explained as a haplology of the same form.

VEWT 66, EDT 295-296, ЭСТЯ 2, 128-129, TMN 2, 382, Лексика 168. VEWT 70, EDT 348-349, ЭСТЯ 2, 106-107, TMN 4, 35, Лексика 195, Stachowski 178. Turk. > MMong. mĳe, mĳi (Щербак 1997, 105).
VEWT 79, EDT 311, ЭСТЯ 2, 183. Turk. > WMong. boɣ, Kalm. \Ibog\i (KW 48-49; see TMN 2, 349, Щербак 1997, 108).

REFERENCE: EDT 405, VEWT 94. Forms apparently pointing to *čɨk- most probably reflect a contraction of the suffixed form *čɨgɨ-k-.
VEWT 119, EDT 405, 407, Stachowski 114.

CHV: čъvъš 'sound of the whip or rod', čъʷvaš-la- 'to lash'
REFERENCE: EDT 395. See also under *čɨ̄p.
VEWT 10, EDT 273, ЭСТЯ 1, 249-251. Turk. > WMong. ajman- (Щербак 1997, 96); but Mong. *aju- can be hardly regarded as a Turkism.
EDT 37-38, VEWT 164, ЭСТЯ 1, 332-333, Егоров 354, Stachowski 263.
EDT 110, VEWT 169, ЭСТЯ 1, 367-369, Лексика 106.

VEWT 170, EDT 99, ЭСТЯ 1, 336-337, Егоров 77. Az., Turk., Gag. have a secondary voicing due to early contraction *-ĳi- > *-ī-. Turk. > Mong. \Iig\i 'spindle' (Щербак 1997, 123); the derivative *ĳik-lig (Chag. ikliɣ 'violin', cf. Khak. īk id. (see VEWT 179) > Kalm. ikəĺə (KW 206).
VEWT 172, 203, Лексика 151, Stachowski 129.
VEWT 178, ЭСТЯ 4, 65-67, Дыбо 139-141, Лексика 242.

ОСНЯ 3, 58-59, ЭСТЯ 4, 77-78, EDT 981. PT *jańka- is usually treated as derived from *jāj- 'to shake, rinse' (see e.g. ЭСТЯ 4, 75-76, EDT ibid.), but the latter does not seem to show any traces of nasal and may be separately compared with Mong. ǯaji-lu- 'to rinse', ǯaji-mu- 'to shake, stir', see KW 471.
EDT 885, VEWT 204, ЭСТЯ 4, 204-205, Stachowski 116.

EDT 955, VEWT 208, ЭСТЯ 4, 223-224. Turk. > Mong. jor- (Щербак 1997, 125). The root should be distinguished from *jȫr- 'to untie, release' (Yak. süör-, OT jör-) - the latter  is different both phonetically and semantically, although it can, through contamination, also attain the meaning 'to interpret' (thus in MK and OUygh.).

EDT 986, VEWT 214, TMN 2, 146,147-148, ЭСТЯ 1, 623-625, 4, 260, 261-262, Егоров 212, Лексика 548-549, Stachowski 115. Turk. > Hung. gyú ́rű (see Lig. MNyTK 77-79). The reason of *j- > 0- in the PT name of stirrup" ( < *"ring-formed") is unclear (irregular change in a long form?)."
VEWT 218, TMN 3, 183, ЭСТЯ 5, 214-215, Лексика 122, Федотов 2, 366, Stachowski 141.

CHG: kertme 'яблоко, груша' (OKypch.: AH, Houts., CCum.), kirni 'quince'
REFERENCE: VEWT 257. Perhaps < *gürt-me, cf. the attested OT (MK-Osm., see EDT 738) kürt 'mountain tree for making bows, Pyrus'; (AH)  kürt 'quince'.

MEANING: 1 to sew, sew together 2 leather belt

REFERENCE: VEWT 233, ЭСТЯ 5, 197-198, Stachowski 137 (nasalization in Dolg. is unclear).

RUSMEAN: 1 запрет 2 назначать наказание, обвинять, штрафовать 3 усталый, разбитый 4 издеваться 5 вина, недостаток 6 устанавливать, назначать 7 упрямый 8 говорить грубо, мешать, подводить 9 голодать, испытывать нужду

REFERENCE: VEWT 258.

REFERENCE: VEWT 260.

REFERENCE: VEWT 182, EDT 929, 930, ЭСТЯ 4, 97-98, 104-106. Turk. > Kalm. jalŋ (KW 214). Cf. also *jalkɨ 'single' (ЭСТЯ 4, 95), Stachowski 106, 118.  Yak. sɨgɨnńax < *jalŋɨn-čak; soɣotox < *jalŋoŕak.

REFERENCE: VEWT 166.

VEWT 290-291, EDT 724, ЭСТЯ 3, 72-73, Лексика 384, 476-477. Cf. also *gȫnčük 'an ornament on shirt' (ЭСТЯ 5, 106).
VEWT 214, EDT 578, ЭСТЯ 5, 160-161, 6, 7-8. This root should be distinguished from *Kāpuk 'bark' (v. sub *k`ā́p`à), although they are partially confused in VEWT 234-5. See also EDT 583.
EDT 976, VEWT 202, ЭСТЯ 4, 44, Лексика 94-95, Stachowski 105.

DT 948, ЭСТЯ 4, 123-124. The root is traditionally considered merely a variant of *jạjŋak 'cheek, jaw' (v. sub *zi̯ā̀ni), but it may be possible to separate them etymologically. Tat. > Chuv. janax > Mari, Udm. janak (Федотов 2, 500).
EDT 306, TMN 2, 812, Лексика 316.
EDT 767, VEWT 342, ЭСТЯ 7.
EDT 700, VEWT 246, ЭСТЯ 3, 12-13, Лексика 472-473, Stachowski 146.

VEWT 455, EDT 567, ЭСТЯ 3, 125-127, Федотов 2, 259-260, Stachowski 215. Turk. *daja-k 'staff' [perhaps rather *dajna-k because of Tof. and Yak. forms: Yak. tajax, taj̃ax, Dolg. tajax, tańak, see Stachowski 215, 216) > WMong. tajaɣ, Kalm. tajəg (KW 374-375, TMN 2, 445, Щербак 1997, 152).
VEWT 210, EDT 919. Turk. > Mong. ǯula (KW 479, Щербак 1997, 125), whence Evk. ǯula (Doerfer MT 125).

MEANING: 1 to cut (off edges), make notches 2 to click 3 to pinch 4 to pinch (a musical instrument)

CHV: śart 'a dent for inserting bottom into banded vessels'
REFERENCE: VEWT 105, EDT 428, Федотов 2, 87-88. The semantic development here is 'to make notches, indents' > 'break the edge', 'pinch' (whence 'to click with fingers') - not onomatopoetic, as suggested by Clauson.
VEWT 101, EDT 399, TMN 3, 35-38. Criticism of the hypothesis of the word's Iranian origin see in TMN.
EDT 38-39, 64, VEWT 517, ЭСТЯ 1, 609, 610-611, Stachowski 247.
EDT 802, VEWT 414, Лексика 380, ЭСТЯ 7. The Turk. derivative *sɨdrɨm > (MK) sɨδrɨm, Ogh. sɨrɨm was probably borrowed in Mong. sirin 'unworked leather'.
EDT 2-3, VEWT 368. Derived is probably *ȫ-g 'thought', *ȫg-re- 'to learn' (see ЭСТЯ 1, 496-498, 501-502, Stachowski 198, 252).
VEWT 368, EDT 67-68.
Ашм. XVI, 226-227. Isolated in Chuvash, but having probable external parallels.

EDT 160, VEWT 42, ЭСТЯ 1, 275. The noun *emgek 'crawling' is preserved in Tur. dial. imek, Chag. emgek 'crawling child' (and, despite Clauson ibid. it certainly has nothing to do with *emgek 'worry, pains', see *emge-). Cf. also forms like Turkm. eŋkej- 'bow' and Yak., Dolg. üŋk- 'to bow' (contractions?); see Stachowski 251.
VEWT 373, EDT 172, ЭСТЯ 1, 536, Лексика 233.

Stachowski 199.
VEWT 495, EDT 533, ЭСТЯ 3, 283-284, Stachowski 228. The Turkm. voicedness is unclear.

REFERENCE: VEWT 224. EDT 615-616. Chuv. xullen is derived (by Tekin 1975, 281) from PT *K(i)aĺaŋ (v. sub *ki̯oĺa), but it rather belongs here.

EDT 333, 336, VEWT 60, Мудрак Дисс. 179, Лексика 374. Turk. > Mong. balčig (Щербак 1997, 103). In Chuv. one would rather expect pɨśəx, so the form may reflect a slightly different morphologically *bạlɨ-čak.

VEWT 493, ЭСТЯ 3, 279-281, Федотов 215, Stachowski 228.

Usually regarded as derived from *jār- 'split' (q. v. sub *p`i̯ā́rV),  which may be possible if Khalaj length is original; however, shortness in Turkm. jara, as well as the probable connection with Mong. *sirka 'wound' is contradicting it.

REFERENCE: EDT 159, VEWT 42, ЭСТЯ 1, 272-275, 25-26. Turk. > Mong. emge- (Щербак 1997, 114).

VEWT 468, 470. Федотов 2, 165-166 connects the Chuv. form with PT *takɨr  'level, smooth' (which is possible if Chuv. < Tat.), in which case the Chuvash form should be removed from this etymology.

RUSMEAN: 1 нечетный 2 единственный, только 3 ничего не понимающий 4 ноль 5 напрасный, напрасно
REFERENCE: VEWT 470, TMN 2, 660, EDT 475. Turk. > Mong. Khalkha \Iteg\i `zero', Kalm. \Iteg\i 'kurz, niedrig' (KW 389).
VEWT 472, EDT 507. Turk. > WMong. tebene, temene id. (KW 391, TMN 4, 278-279, Щербак 1997, 154).
VEWT 474, EDT 528, ЭСТЯ 3, 203-204. Chuvash dialects show a variation between e/ẹ.

MEANING: 1 to allow, refer to 2 reason, excuse
REFERENCE: VEWT 478, EDT 494 (but not derived from  *dɨl 'tongue'!).

ДТС 84. But cf. perhaps Kirgh. (ep.) burqu 'variety'?
EDT 378.
VEWT 496, EDT 463-464, Рас. ФиЛ 175, Лексика 420.
VEWT 506, EDT 530-531, ЭСТЯ 3, 319-320. Turk. > Hung. tűr- 'to tuck', see Gombocz 1912.

ЭСТЯ 1, 396.
EDT 844 (read as saru which is hardly the case), Лексика 520.  Turk. > WMong. sörü 'support, prop' (L 732).

MEANING: 1 straw 2 brushwood 3 rot, dandruff 4 to hull
REFERENCE: EDT 688 (but not < Sogd.), 689. Cf. also *köbŕe- (*kebŕe-?) 'to hull, pound in a mortar' (ЭСТЯ 5, 81, 82).
EDT 688; ЭСТЯ 5, 47.
EDT 676, VEWT 301, Лексика 576, ЭСТЯ 6, 111, 113, Stachowski 161. Turk. > Mong. qujiqa 'skin from the head' (whence Evk. kuika etc., see Doerfer MT 132; Dolg. kujka 'head skin', see Stachowski 160).
VEWT 477, TMN 2, 508, EDT 574, Федотов 2, 236. Chuv. > Tat., Bashk. \Itires.\i

RUSMEAN: 1 смертельный яд 2 дизентерия 3 болезнь, связанная с язвами
KRG: talō-lo-n- 'to become covered by red blots'
REFERENCE: VEWT 458, EDT 496. Despite Clauson, hardly derived from tala- 'to harm, rob'. Modern Oghuz forms (Tur. dial. dalak 'Siberian plague', Az. dial. dalax 'cattle disease', Turkm. dālaq 'camel disease') are restructured on analogy with *d(i)ālak 'spleen' (v. sub *ti̯ṓle).  A similarly reinterpreted form is Chuv. talak 'some inner disease of cattle' - borrowed from Tatar talawu (see above), but restructured under the influence of the borrowed talaq 'spleen'.
VEWT 179, ЭСТЯ 4, 80-81, Лексика 178, Федотов 2, 129.
VEWT 271, EDT 735-736, ЭСТЯ 3, 47-48, Stachowski 149.

EDT 91, ЭСТЯ 1, 461; Stachowski 194. Derived is PT *oŋur-tka 'spine, backbone' (see ЭСТЯ 1, 463-464).

EDT 101-102, ЭСТЯ 1, 618-619. The root clearly has a *-k-, with a development > *-g- > *-ɣ- in Oghuz pointing to an original long vowel. It should be therefore distinguished from PT *ög- 'to knead, press' which shows only reflexes of *-g-.
ЭСТЯ 2, 142-143, EDT 332-333 (< \I*bi\i 'blade', denom. - but Turkm. shortness contradicts this derivation). Turk. *bile-gü > Mong. *bile-ɣü id., see Щербак 1997, 106.
VEWT 12, Radloff 1, 48, 222. Cf. also Khak. ajɣɨ 'smooth, polished' (VEWT 11).

MEANING: 1 a k. of tent 2 tent covering
REFERENCE: Лексика 515. Tur. turluk, Turkm. durluG show irregular reflexation; we may be dealing with some interlingual loans here; the quality of the initial dental in PT is thus not quite clear.

MEANING: to dry off, peter out (of liquids)
REFERENCE: VEWT 425, EDT 809, Stachowski 244.

KRH: topun 'wheat chaff' (MK; EDT glosses 'a lump of food', probably incorrectly)
REFERENCE: ЭСТЯ 8; despite Tekin 1969, 65 should be kept distinct from *topraq 'dust'.
VEWT 426, ЭСТЯ 6.
VEWT 221. If the original meaning is 'air movement' (cf. the external evidence), cf. also Chuv. \Ikü\i 'strong odour'.
EDT 3.

MEANING: a part of human or animal trunk
KRH: bökseg 'woman's breast; upper part of chest' (MK)
CHG: bökse 'the part of a human or animal body above the waist' (Abush., Sangl.)
UZB: bụksa 'side part of the body below the breast and down to the hip; (dial.) lower part of body'
REFERENCE: EDT 329, VEWT 84, 83, ЭСТЯ 2, 213-214, Лексика 278. Forms without -k meaning 'buttock' or 'lower part of body' are most probably borrowed < Mong. *bögse, having quite different origin (see under *pi̯oko) - although some contaminations were not excluded.
VEWT 433, TMN 3, 287, ЭСТЯ 7.

RUSMEAN: 1 рыжий (о масти лошади) 2 олень, джейран, антилопа
REFERENCE: ЭСТЯ 4, 22-24, 36. Turk. > Mong. ǯeɣir-, ǯeɣerde (TMN 1, 289, 4, 184) > Sol. ǯegerẽ 'antelope', Man. ǯerde (see Doerfer MT 136) > MKor. čjərta (măr) (see Lee 1958, 119). Pers. ǯejran ( < Turk. or Mong.) is widely borrowed back into Turkic (Tur., Az. ǯejran etc.).

TRM: bašmaq, pašmaq (heel of a camel; boot")"
REFERENCE: EDT 382-383, ЭСТЯ 2, 93-95, ОСНЯ III 69, TMN 2, 293-294. Doerfer's inner etymology (bašmak with vowel elision < *baša-mak from *baša- 'to cut, make notches') is impossible: baša- is derived from *bāĺ(č) 'wound' with a long vowel, while bašmak has a short one.
VEWT 180, ЭСТЯ 4, 82.

MEANING: 1 sacrifice 2 price, sale 3 engagement, votive 4 gift
RUSMEAN: 1 жертвоприношение 2 цена, продажа 3 помолвка, обет 4 подарок
REFERENCE: VEWT 5. All the listed forms may be derived from *āta- `to name' ( < *āt `name'), but the specific meanings rather suggest a secondary contamination.

EDT 967, VEWT 189, 190, ЭСТЯ 4, 143, Лексика 334-335. The most widely spread form, attested since Old Uyghur,  is *jar-lɨ(g) 'poor'; the evidence of Oyr., Tuva, Kirgh. and Kaz., however, suggests the existence of a primary stem *jar(ɨ)- 'thin, lean'. Turk. > Hung. gyarló 'sinful' (< *jarlɨɣ), see Gombocz 1912.
VEWT 427, EDT 826, ЭСТЯ 7, Федотов 2, 57.

MEANING: 1 face 2 be similar 3 open forestless place on a mountain slope
RUSMEAN: 1 внешность, вид, лицо 2 быть похожим 3 открытое безлесное место на склоне горы
REFERENCE: VEWT 70, EDT 352, Лексика 208, ЭСТЯ 7, ФиЛ 207. In Chuv. cf. either min 'face colour' (if not = min 'red spot on face', see Лексика 208) or *paŋ > Proto-Perm.*baŋ  (Лыткин-Гуляев 37). Turk. > MMong. meŋiz 'comparison, metaphor' (Щербак 1997, 129).
EDT 38, VEWT 174, ЭСТЯ 1, 386-387, Stachowski 129, 254.
Морфология 23-26, 28, 32.
EDT 919, ЭСТЯ 4, 21-22. Turk. > WMong. ǯele (rather than vice versa, despite VEWT 125).

MEANING: 1 to go apart, scatter, spread 2 to branch, be forked  3 branch 4 claw 5 finger
RUSMEAN: 1 расходиться, рассеиваться, распространяться 2 растопыриваться, разветвляться 3 ветвь 4 лапа 5 палец
REFERENCE: VEWT 463, EDT 529, ЭСТЯ 3, 150-151, Дыбо 312, Лексика 256, Федотов 2, 251, Stachowski 218. Widely spread modern Kypchak forms like Kirgh. tara-, tarqa- 'to become scattered' etc. are most probably < Mong. tara-, tarqa- (see under *t`ájri), since the (rather scanty) Oghuz evidence points to *d-, so Clauson (EDT 529) may be right in thinking that there is no etymological connection between PT *dar- and Mong. tara-, tarqa- 'disperse'. It is also probable that the common Turkic derivatives *darma- 'to scrape, rake up; to scatter,  disperse in different directions', as well as *dara- 'to comb' (ЭСТЯ 3, 147-149, Stachowski 217) can belong here - although both roots tend to contaminate actively with PT *dɨrŋa- 'to scrape' (q. v. sub *či̯ŭru).
ЭСТЯ 1, 236-237, 335-336, Мудрак Дисс. 171, Лексика 377.
Борг. 629.

(see EDT 443). Words meaning 'cone' reflect a partial contamination with PT *Tobur- 'cone' (v. sub *t`obú).

MEANING: 1 infant's urinal in a cradle 2 pivot (of a hand-mill etc.)  3 corn-cob

REFERENCE: EDT 788, ЭСТЯ 7. Modern languages reveal some very irregular reflexes like Kaz., KKalp. sobɨq 3, Tur. sümek, sömek 1, 2, 3 (with -m- also in Kum. sümek, Nogh. simek, Uzb. sumak 1, 2 etc.; some languages have variants with č- or š- like Kirgh. čömök 3, šimek 1, 2). These all can be either irregular expressive variants with secondary diffusion or reflect contaminations with some other (not quite clear) roots.

MEANING: 1 seed, cereals, crops; 2 graft, 3 vaccine, 4 pus (primarily  - as a material for vaccinacion?) 5 tanning matter, 6 starch
RUSMEAN: 1 семя, злаки, зерновые 2 привой 3 вакцина 4 гной (первоначально - как прививка?) 5 дубильное вещество 6 крахмал
HAK: \Ias\i 1, as-ta-n- 'to beware of a disease' ('to vaccinate oneself'?)
JAK: \Ias\i 4, \Ias,\i ahɨlɨk 'fruit of some wild plants, berry'
KRG: \Iaš\i 'fruit of some wild plants, berry', aštɨq 1, aša- 'to tan'
GAGX: haš-la- 'to plant out seedlings; to graft; to vaccinate'
REFERENCE: VEWT 30, ЭСТЯ 1, 211-212, 216, Stachowski 29. A lot of etymological confusion here. Forms meaning 'to tan, tanning matter; starch' may be either borrowed from Persian or, rather, derived from *(i)aĺ 'meal' (v. sub *i̯oĺe), see Лексика 378.  The latter root, due to its phonetic similarity (or even identity) has in general influenced the present one: 'cereals' are influenced by 'porridge' and *(i)aĺ-la- 'to graft, to pollinate' by *(i)aĺ-la- 'to fertilize' ( = 'to feed'). It seems nevertheless impossible to unite them completely.
VEWT 358. Usually derived from *ogul 'son', which is rather dubious for external reasons. See Мудрак Дисс. 146. Дыбо 156.

REFERENCE: VEWT 251. Widely spread forms like Chag. kämirčäk are probably due to contamination with *kEmük 'bone' (v. sub *k`i̯ome).

MEANING: 1 place 2 palace 3 lair, den 4 middle 5 place of staying (of the army, ruler etc.) 6 army
RUSMEAN: 1 место 2 дворец 3 берлога, логово 4 середина 5 место стоянки (армии, правителя) 6 армия
REFERENCE: EDT 203-204, 233, VEWT 364, 365, TMN 2, 141, ЭСТЯ 1, 470-472, 474-479, Лексика 495, 563, 569, Stachowski 193, 196. Turkic is the source of Mong. oron 'place', ordo(n) 'palace' (cf. TMN 1, 164-165, 2, 38-39,  Щербак 1997, 130), whence Man. oron etc., see Doerfer MT 116. The PT *ordu 'place of staying' may need to be separated from other forms here: it contains a very untypical *-rd- cluster (as opposed to *or-tu 'middle') and may reflect an ancient borrowing from some unknown source. Cf. in that respect WMong. örte- 'to change post horses', örtegen 'postal relay station', also somewhat obscure in origin.

MEANING: 1 echo 2 sound, resound 3 to sound, pronounce

The stem should be probably distinguished historically from *Koĺ- 'to couple, bind', although contaminations were possible.  Turk. > Russ. \Iкушак\i (Дмитриев 1958, 28, Шипова 216).

Лексика 29, 35. The derivative *čar-s is somewhat peculiar morphologically and could be a loanword - from the (unattested) Mong. *čar-su(n) (?). {Oyr. čarɨm was removed from this etymology, but probably unjustly: the Komi source ćare̮m 'snow crust', as well as ćars id. are much better explained as borrowed from Turkic than vice versa. The form is traced back to Ur. *śarV in Réd. 464, but the consonantism is quite irregular; other parallels proposed by Helimsky are Saam. čar\Ha\hva - with irregular vocalism - and Selk. č́ɔ̄rpɨ, closely resembling Tofalar čarpɨŋ. A complicated case, but explanation of the existing scattered Uralic forms from Turkic is at least not preferable to vice versa.}

REFERENCE: VEWT 116, 118-119, Егоров 320, Федотов  2, 403. An expressive and late attested root; appears, however, to be reconstructable for PT. RUSMEAN: 1 уходить с дороги, отклоняться 2 окольная дорога 3 уловка, трюк
REFERENCE: VEWT 402, EDT 784, ЭСТЯ 7, Ашм. XI, 187, Федотов 2, 64.

EDT 911, ЭСТЯ 4, 197-198, VEWT 202-203. On the derived *jib-sek ( > *jüb-sek, *jüg-sek) 'thimble' see ЭСТЯ 4, 257-258, Stachowski 117. Bulg. > Hung. szű- in szűcz 'furrier, tailor' (*jib-či), cf. MNyTESz 3, 810.

MEANING: 1 a k. of weed 2 a sort of wheat with very light grains
RUSMEAN: 1 костер дантониевидный 2 сорт пшеницы с легкими зернами
REFERENCE: The root is poorly reflected and hardly reliable.
The Chuvash form points to *-ɨ-. The root is very localized, but seems to be distinct from *čɨm- / *čum- 'top; stick with a knob' (although a contamination was of course possible).

VEWT 97. Dmitrieva (Дмитриева 1979, 205) derives the Oghuz word for 'fir-tree' from Arab. šam 'candle', which is dubious phonetically and unlikely because of the Khak. and Shor forms (pointing to *čamal); more probably an original Turkic root, although localized.

MEANING: 1 top, upper part 2 staff (with a knob) 3 lump, pompon, knob
RUSMEAN: 1 верхушка 2 палка (с набалдашником) 3 комок, помпон, набалдашник
REFERENCE: VEWT 115, TMN 2, 94-95, EDT 422. The Chuv. reflex points to *-ɨ-.
Егоров  210, Федотов 2, 108, Мудрак Дисс. 137.
VEWT 176, ЭСТЯ 4, 34. Turk. > WMong. ǯabu(l)či, Khalkha ʒūč id. (hardly vice versa, despite Rona-Tas KM II 125-126).
Дыбо 194 (though hardly a loanword).

MEANING: 1 chap, saddle-gall on back of an animal 2 wound, chafe on human body
RUSMEAN: 1 ссадина на спине животного 2 рана, ссадина на человеческом теле
REFERENCE: ЭСТЯ 4, 65, TMN 4, 183. External evidence suggests that this root should be kept distinct from *jagɨr, *jagrɨn 'back, shoulderblade' (v. sub *dagV).
EDT 845.

MEANING: 1 outer angle 2 protruding edge of a mountain or wall
RUSMEAN: 1 внешний угол 2 выступ горы или стены
TRK: senir (dial.) 'hill between valleys, ridge between mountains'
REFERENCE: VEWT 410, EDT 840, Лексика 98, ЭСТЯ 7.
ЭСТЯ 4, 146; Лексика 384, Stachowski 98.
EDT 184, VEWT 172, ЭСТЯ 1, 358-361, Егоров 64, Лексика 436, 447-448). Turk. > Mong. iŋgen 'female camel'; Hung. ünő 'heifer' (Gombocz 1912).

ATU: imiti (Rach.) (can also be read as ɨmɨt)
REFERENCE: ДТС 209. Attested only in Old Uyghur, but having possible parallels in Tung. and Jpn. Turk. > Mong. imidi (the word has been pointed out by Stefan Georg, who found it out in Позднеев: Учебник тибетской медицины (1908 г.), 339); cf. also WMong. imdĳ, Khalkha imdĳ 'боярышник полуперистый' (БАМРС). The Turkic word is, of course, not from Mongolian (which certainly has a borrowed shape with -d- in front of -i).

MEANING: 1 capers 2 ferment for milk 3 a k. of fermented milk drink
RUSMEAN: 1 каперсы 2 закваска для молока 3 вид квашенного молочного напитка
REFERENCE: Егоров 103. Kirgh. > Kalm. kȫrcəg (see differently in KW 244, Лексика 451).

MEANING: 1 to be proud, arrogant, enjoy self-respect 2 to hope 3 proud
REFERENCE: VEWT 306, EDT 690, ЭСТЯ 3, 91-92.
ЭСТЯ 3, 63-64, VEWT 295.

HAK: xɨsxar- 'to reproach, blame', xɨǯɨr- 'to tease smb.'
REFERENCE: EDT 59.

Лексика 528. Formally derived from *bastɨr- 'to cause to press' - which seems rather far-fetched semantically. We may deal here rather with a  compound of *bas + *terme 'wall, building', secondary influenced by *bastɨr-ma, *bastɨr-ɨk 'pole for fixing hay and sheaves', see  ЭСТЯ 2, 76-77.
VEWT 432, EDT 816 (confused with sogur- 'to drain off, dry off' - probably a different root, see *sog-, *sogul-), ЭСТЯ 7.

EDT 816. Федотов 2, 466-467 derives the Chuv. form < *sōr(a)- 'ask' (v. sub *sṓra), but the initial š- remains unclear in both cases. Because of this, and because of the Hapax nature of the OT form the it is actually not quite clear whether the root *sogra- exists at all. An argument in its favour is the semantic match between OT and Chagatai and the resulting semantic distinction (*'search (through)') from *sōr(a)- 'ask'.

MEANING: to thrust the hand (into one's bosom)
REFERENCE: EDT 810.
VEWT 53, EDT 335, ЭСТЯ 2, 88-89. Turk. > Bur. bala 'bruise, injury'.

MEANING: 1 to be destroyed, ruined 2 to destroy
REFERENCE: VEWT 92, EDT 332.

VEWT 426, ЭСТЯ 7. Stachowski (193) relates here also Yak. ono-ɣos, Dolg. ono-gos 'arrow', which may be right if onoɣos < *sagun-gač with secondary vowel shortening (although the root should be kept distinct from *sokɨm / *sokan, derived from *sok- 'to pierce, hit' - medial *-g- cannot be explained). See also notes to *sagut 'vessel'.
VEWT 485. A local Syberian form, probably a compound of the expected *dog- with some obscure second component (possibly *dog-kumtɨŕ 'weasel-beaver').

TRK: čakɨl- 'to be bound, fastened' (of yoke animals), čaɣan 'camel fetters'
REFERENCE: VEWT 94, 96 (but Oyr. čakɨ is regarded as borrowed < Mong. čaqu, on which see *č`ak`V).
EDT 898.
EDT 815, VEWT 416, 425, ЭСТЯ 7.
VEWT 195, Stachowski 103.
EDT 700 (with a quite dubious hypothesis of borrowing < Sogd.).

MEANING: 1 a complicated affair with no obvious way out 2 to be sad, tired 3 to rave 4 fool
RUSMEAN: 1 затруднительное дело, положение 2 быть печальным, усталым 3 бредить 4 глупец
REFERENCE: EDT 830.

VEWT 501, Stachowski 230. Turk. > MMong. (MA) tusa, WMong. tusa 'help, service' (see Clark 1977, 157, Щербак 1997, 159; not vice versa, despite Sinor 1970), whence Man. tusa etc., see Doerfer MT 100, and possibly some modern Turkic forms as backloans.
EDT 361-362, ЭСТЯ 2, 116-120, Stachowski 58.
EDT 165, VEWT 43, ЭСТЯ 1, 352, Егоров 26, Stachowski 122.

MEANING: 1 coquetry 2 cockering, endearment 3 cockered, beloved 4 entertainment , joke
RUSMEAN: 1 кокетство 2 баловство, ласка 3 избалованный, любимый 4 забава, шутка
REFERENCE: VEWT 48, ЭСТЯ 1, 296-297, 300-301, TMN 2, 181-182. The root is widely spread, although unattested in older sources; its relationship to *eriĺ- 'contest' (suggested in ЭСТЯ 297) is dubious.
VEWT 63, ЭСТЯ 2, 66-68, Дыбо 319-320, Лексика 253-255.
EDT 55, VEWT 510, ЭСТЯ 1, 578-579, Лексика 282.

EDT 338-339, VEWT 76, TMN 2, 314, ЭСТЯ 2, 145-146, Дыбо 172-175 (with detailed analysis of phonetic variants and derivatives), Лексика 256. Turk. *bilek-jüŕük > *bile(g)ŕük 'bracelet' (EDT 345, Stachowski 60) > Mong. bilüčüg / bilisüg / bülüǯüg (see Clark 1980, 41).

EDT 962, VEWT 190, ЭСТЯ 4, 147. Modern languages widely reflect *jarak 'weapon, armour' (Kirgh. ǯaraq, Uygh. jaraq etc., see ЭСТЯ 4, 139). This seems to be a contamination of the earlier attested *jarag 'readiness, opportunity' (derived from *jara- 'to be fit, suitable' q. v. sub *ǯắra;  see EDT ibid.) and *jarɨk 'armour'.
EDT 672.
VEWT 200, EDT 897.

MEANING: 1 coniferous forest 2 pistacio nut 3 (fruit) stone, seed 4 hazel-nut 5 wild jujube 6 young coniferous growth 7 bush, shrub 8 fir branch
RUSMEAN: 1 лес (хвойный) 2 фисташковый орех 3 косточка, семечко 4 лесной орех 5 дикая ююба 6 молодые хвойные поросли 7 кустарник 8 ветка ели
REFERENCE: VEWT 102, EDT 867-868. Morphologically -t - is a collective suffix, -dak/-dɨk - a denominative suffix. The word is attested in MK, but in an aberrant (dialectal) shape with š-, and the meaning 'nut' is probably secondary, the original meaning of the root being 'coniferous tree, branch'. Several  other plant names may be related, cf.: Chag. čekɛ 'berries found in the Fergana mountains'; Uzb. čakanda 'облепиха крушиновидная', Uygh. čäkändä 'a bush with red fruits' (R 3, 1947 Taranchi, mod. čakanda 'a k. of thorny bush'), Az.  čäkil 'mulberry'; Kirgh. South. čekende 'хвойник; кузьмичева трава; эфедра двуколосковая' (its pseudoberries are edible; despite Yudakhin, not < Iranian - the word is not attested in Persian). Turk. > Pers. \Ičäkäldäk\i 'blackberry' (Гафаров).
VEWT 281,  EDT 588, TMN 3, 535-537, Лексика 614, ЭСТЯ 69-71.
ЭСТЯ 5, 312.
VEWT 285, EDT 688, ЭСТЯ 3, 52, Федотов 1, 247. Cf. also probably from the same root: Chuv. kəʷpśa 'vagina', Tat. köpšä 'pipe-like stalk'.
ЭСТЯ 5, 174, EDT 583.

CHG: qova (AH), qopqa (Pav. C., Бор. Бад., Abush.)
REFERENCE: EDT 583-584, ЭСТЯ 6, 12-13. Turk. > Mong. qobuɣa 'bucket, trough'.
ЭСТЯ 5, 33. Cf. also such forms as Chuv. kiźep 'tamper, pestle' and Bashk. ki(l)sap, kilϑap id. Turk. > Hung. kölyű, see Gombocz 1912.

MEANING: 1 expensive, miserly 2 to wish, envy, be miserly
REFERENCE: VEWT 269, EDT 680, Лексика 339, ЭСТЯ 6, 248-249. The root is also attested as kɨrs in Tur. dialects, and as qɨrzan- in Tuva The verbal form *Kɨŕ-gan- is sometimes attested as qɨsɣan- due to a contamination with *Kɨs-ga- 'short, narrow' (v. sub *kíso).

MEANING: 1 to be irritated, agitated 2 to move; irritate
REFERENCE: ОСНЯ 3, 132-133. The roots *Kōŕ- 'to be hungry' and *Kōŕ- 'to be agitated' are usually considered to be a single root and are very hard to distinguish within Turkic.
ЭСТЯ 1, 403.

EDT 328. The word is also present in some Iranian languages (Sogd. βɣ'ny, Osset. bägäny, where it is most probably a Turkic loanword, despite TMN 2, 311, Bailey 320 [with a dubious Iranian etymology]). Turk. > Mong. bekni, begni, see Щербак 1997, 193.
EDT 835, VEWT 417, ЭСТЯ 7 (the root should be distinguished from *sɨjn 'body, idol' q. v. sub *si̯ùnu, although they tend to contaminate). Turk. > Mong. sina-, see Щербак 1997, 145.

MEANING: 1 to hide, conceal (trans.) 2 to hide (intr.) 3 to get lost
REFERENCE: Егоров 173, Федотов I 466-467, EDT 308, ЭСТЯ 2, 78-79: the root should be distinguished from \I*bat-\i 'to sink' (v. sub *pàt`á).

MEANING: 1 to whet, sharpen 2 to rub teeth
REFERENCE: ЭСТЯ 5, 205. The Turk. derivative *kajɨrak 'whetstone' > Mong. qajiraɣ, see TMN 3, 568-569. Cf. also Kaz., Tat. qajau 'notch', Tur. qajaɣan 'whetstone' (R 2, 90) and Yak. xajgɨa, xojguo 'notch'; Yak. xaja, Dolg. kaja '(to tear) apart', Yak. xajɨt- 'to break, tear apart', Dolg. kajɨt- id., kajɨn- (itr.) (see Stachowski 133, 134, 135).

MEANING: 1 to stick in 2 sting 3 to  sew
RUSMEAN: 1 втыкать 2 жало 3 сшивать строчкой, оторачивать, вышивать
REFERENCE: EDT 596, ЭСТЯ 5, 180-181. The root should be distinguished from *Kāta- 'to stick in, nail' (v. sub *kā́jta).

MEANING: 1 to tear out, uproot 2 to break 3 to move
REFERENCE: VEWT 284, ЭСТЯ 6, 85-86.
VEWT 241, TMN 4, 393, EDT 593. Somewhat dubious: the word may represent a rendering of Sanskr. khaḍga 'rhinoceros' (through Tokharian?); cf. OUygh. ktki 'id.'.
EDT 339, VEWT 69, 72, ЭСТЯ VI.

MEANING: 1 a wooden hammer for processing boot seams 2 to hit, pound
RUSMEAN: 1 деревянный молоточек для обивки обувных швов 2 бить, колотить
JAK: kübürgē- 'to hit ice with a pounder'
REFERENCE: Modern expressive formations, but the root seems to be archaic.

EDT 911, VEWT 202, ЭСТЯ 1, 325-326, Лексика 122, 140. Turk. (Bulg.) > Hung. szőlő 'grape' (<*śiδleɣ), see Gombocz 1912, MNyTESz 3, 794. Turk. *jigde > Mong. ǯigde, ǯegde (Щербак 1997, 123); but the TM forms are not borrowed, despite Doerfer MT 73.

One of expressive common Turkic roots meaning 'round, spherical'. See VEWT 210, EDT 871, 873, 877, 936, 937-8, ЭСТЯ 4, 246-247, 249-250. The root has also a variant (expressive?) *jub-, see ЭСТЯ 4, 237-238, Stachowski 114.
VEWT 483, EDT 463.
EDT 657, 660 (hardly from Pers. qurbān, but rather vice versa), ЭСТЯ 6, 163, 164.

VEWT 308. An exclusively Oghuz word; traditionally derived from Pers. kuma 'stack, hut' (see Лексика 499), but a reverse direction of borrowing cannot be excluded. Cf. perhaps Karakh. (MK) kümi 'name of a town on the Uyghur border' (?).

TRK: koburčuk, dial. kapurǯak 1, dial. kabzak, kabsak 2
REFERENCE: EDT 587, ЭСТЯ 5, 276-278. Tekin (1979, 127) cites Uygh. qapɨz 'coffin', but we were unable to find the word either in Old or Mod. Uyghur. Perhaps he meant Karakh. xafsɨ 'small box' (MK, see EDT 587).  Brockelmann derived the word from Lat. capsa through Syr. qafsā, but a loan in Turkic < Syr. is not quite probable, and the word might well be genuine. But modern forms: Tur. dial. kapsa 'box, chest', (CCum.) qapsa 'box, coffin' may well be < Syr. (cf. ЭСТЯ 5, 277).

MEANING: 1 coat of mail 2 ring of mail 3 earring 4 overcoat 5 saddle-pad for a camel 6 film of egg, exuviae 7 a k. of cloth or carpet
RUSMEAN: 1 кольчуга 2 кольцо кольчуги 3 серьга 4 плащ, пальто 5 верблюжье седло 6 пленка яйца, сброшенная кожа 7 вид ткани или ковра
REFERENCE: EDT 687, 688, 689, ЭСТЯ 5, 48-49, 108 (Tur. köpen being attributed here to a quite different root, see under *köp- 'to swell, foam'), 114-115, 129-130, TMN 3, 581-583. The above forms are hard to separate, and Doerfer's point of view that köpenek is secondarily < kepenek is probably faulty (even though köpenek is attested later: köpen is certainly attested earlier, and an assimilative delabialization *köpenek > kepenek seems quite plausible). The Chuvash form shows that the original meaning of the root must have been 'transparent covering, film', whence 'coat of mail' etc. Turk. > Mong. kebeneg 'saddle-cloth, shirt', Hung. köpönyeg 'raincoat' (Gombocz 1912).
EDT 692, ЭСТЯ 5, 83. Turk. > Mong. kebis ( > Man. kebisu etc., see ТМС 1, 444), see Clark 1980, 39., Cf. Khalkha xiv 'gauze, crêpe', xövöŋ 'cotton'. ЭСТЯ 5, 13.

MEANING: 1 to take trouble, make efforts 2 to overpower
REFERENCE: EDT 605; Stachowski 154 (but, because of semantic difference, hardly to *Kod- 'put aside').

CHV: (kujan dial. < Tat.) xoŕan, xoren (dial.) **AD  нет в Ашм. и стандартных словарях; откуда? И Левитская в словаре не нашла.
REFERENCE: VEWT 274-275, Лексика 164, ЭСТЯ VI 29-30. Предполагается чув *xoran > марийск. *oren в составе moren 'заяц'  Егоров 122 - скорее маразм.

MEANING: 1 hawk, falcon 2 faultless (of a bird of prey)
RUSMEAN: 1 ястреб, сокол 2 ловкий, бьющий без промаха (о ловчей птице)
TRK: kɨrɣaj, kɨrɣɨ 1,  kuran (dial.) 'hawk', kɨrkaw (dial., R.) 'a k. of hawk'
KRG: qɨrān, qɨran 1, 2, qɨrɣɨj, qɨjɣɨr 1, qɨrɣɨjek 'young hawk'
REFERENCE: VEWT 266, 269, EDT 654-655, ЭСТЯ 6, 231, 232-235. Turk. *Kɨrguj 'falcon' > Mong. kirɣui, see Щербак 1997, 139.
VEWT 308, EDT 717 (incorrectly to kül- 'harness'), ЭСТЯ 3, 95-96.
EDT 930, ЭСТЯ 4, 266, Лексика 263, Stachowski 115.
VEWT 347, EDT 347, 767 (confused with other roots),  ОСНЯ 3, 55-56, ЭСТЯ 7.

MEANING: 1 space between the legs 2 wedge between trouser legs
RUSMEAN: 1 промежуток между ногами 2 клин между штанинами

MEANING: young of a wild animal, puppy
REFERENCE: EDT 183, VEWT 44, ЭСТЯ 1, 281-283, Егоров 29, Stachowski 251.
VEWT 483, 485, ЭСТЯ 8, Егоров 2256, Федотов 2, 242.
Федотов 1, 260. For Chuv. kъrtъš cf. also Tat. qɨrtɨš (the direction of borrowing is unclear).
ОСНЯ 1, 242. The form is poorly attested and rather dubious (the Tuva form may be < Oyr. öj < PT *öd q. v. sub *odi).
VEWT 275, ЭСТЯ 6, 10-11.
VEWT 461, EDT 514, ЭСТЯ 3, 145-146, Stachowski 216. Turk. > Kalm. \Itan-\i 'to plait, knot'.
VEWT 360, EDT 90, ЭСТЯ 1, 585-586. Turk. > Hung. hurok 'loop', see Gombocz 1912.
EDT 285, VEWT 377, ЭСТЯ 1, 508.

JAK: sardaɣa, sardāna 'short heavy arrow with a broad head' (Пек.)
REFERENCE: VEWT 99-100, Егоров 221, Федотов 2, 143 (borrowing < FU *śorva 'horn' is hardly credible). Bulg. > Hung. sarló 'sickle', see Gombocz 1912, MNyTESz 3, 494-495. The root is certainly genuine, although some influence of the Iranian  čarɨk, čarx 'wheel' could have existed.

EDT 369, Лексика 164, TMN 2, 284, ЭСТЯ 7, Егоров 165, Федотов 1, 446-447. Reflexes of  m- in Siberian languages may be due to the nasal in the suffix (cf. the form in MK). Among the traditional derivations one should mention the connection with *bur-sɨ- 'to stink, rot', but external parallels indicate that this is rather a folk etymology.
EDT 767. Turk. > Kalm. manl, Dag. manū (Tod. 153) (probably contaminated with Mong. proper malur < *malul q. v. sub *máĺe). Uygh. molun 'wild cat' may be a mongolism.
Мудрак Дисс. 145. See under *Kạma a discussion of other possible traces of this root.

KRH: qaŋdaš 'half-brother, son of the same father and a different mother' (MK), qaŋsɨq ata 'step-father' (MK)

MEANING: 1 to fasten (with a nail, arrow) 2 to be fastened, attached 3 wooden nail in camel's nose for fastening the tether 4 nail
RUSMEAN: 1 прикреплять, прибивать (гвоздем, стрелой) 2 быть прикрепленным 3 деревянный гвоздик в носовой перегородке верблюда для прикрепления привязи 4 гвоздь
NOGX: bojɨsqan (< *bodɨ-š-kan) 'woollen lead for fastening calves during milking'
REFERENCE: EDT 300, 304, 305, ЭСТЯ 2, 287.  The original meaning of the root is clearly 'to fasten, attach'. The -u-vowel in the name of  camel harness may be a result of borrowing in Karakh. from a Kypchak-type dialect, with further dispersion from Karakh. Тurk. bujla > Mong. bujla 'id.' > Tuva bujla.
VEWT 462, EDT 435, Федотов 2, 248, Stachowski 217.
EDT 448.

MEANING: 1 part of the yurt close to the door 2 threshhold 3 stairs
RUSMEAN: 1 часть юрты рядом с дверью 2 порог 3 лестница
REFERENCE: VEWT 47, Федотов 1, 56-57.
EDT 568.
EDT 113, VEWT 37.

EDT 120-121, TMN 2, 93, ЭСТЯ 1, 126-127. A discussion of albastɨ ( = Mong. albin) see in TMN 2, 109-110. Turk. *āl-da- > Mong. alda- 'to deceive' (MA, cf. also TMN 2, 116, Щербак 1997, 97) > Evk. alda- etc. (Doerfer MT 109). On Mong. alda- 'to lose' see *ā̀le 'weak, tired'.

MEANING: 1 cheek-pouch, inside of the mouth 2 gum 3 mouthful, gulp 4 cheek 5 molar 6 to take a mouthful, swallow
RUSMEAN: 1 внутренняя полость рта 2 десна 3 глоток 4 щека 5 коренной зуб 6 глотать
ATU: a[vurt] (?adurt) (OUygh., late med. texts TT II)
REFERENCE: EDT 65, ЭСТЯ 1, 407-409, Лексика 225-226, Мудрак 115. The Old Uyghur form is poorly readable, so -δ- is dubious. Yak. -m- is irregular: could it be a trace of PA *umV 'drink', otherwise lost in Turkic?
EDT 882, VEWT 176, (incorrectly) Федотов 2, 151.
VEWT 195, ЭСТЯ 4, 172.

MEANING: 1 to be comforted, consoled, entertained 2 to comfort, entertain
REFERENCE: ЭСТЯ 4, 240. Some forms, like Kum. jɨban-, Uzb. jupan- reflect rather *jupa-; the variation of *-b- and *-p- is not quite clear in this root.

MEANING: 1 bogy  2 figure set up to avert the evil eye 3 idol
RUSMEAN: 1 бука 2 фигурка для отвода сглаза 3 идол
REFERENCE: VEWT 1, 2, EDT 6, 8. Quite dubious is the hypothesis (see Аникин 71, TMN 4, 307-310, Clark 1977, 127) of the Turkic forms being borrowed from Mong. abuɣаči 'receiver' (all the more so because the Bur. form is not abāša, but abagša, i. e. reflecting -g-, not -ɣ-). See a detailed discussion in Stachowski  2001.
VEWT 167, ЭСТЯ 1, 667. Despite some mergers with *jɨĺ- (v. sub *ńiĺu), cf. Bashk. jɨšɨ-, jɨšqɨ, this appears to be a separate root.
VEWT 277, ЭСТЯ 6, 42.

MEANING: a neighbour who lives in the same house
RUSMEAN: сосед, живущий в том же доме
REFERENCE: EDT 739. The word is attested only in OT, but modern forms like Oyr. körüš, Tat. kürši 'neighbour' etc. (ЭСТЯ 5, 118-119; > Mong. körši, see Clark 1980, 41) may actually belong here, being transformed under the influence of körüš- 'to see each other'. Difficult is Yak. küre, kürüö 'wife's younger sister': Poppe 1961, 138 regards it as genetically related to the Mongolian forms, but one cannot exclude a secondary loan < Evk. kuriɣen.
EDT 727, ЭСТЯ 3, 20-21, VEWT 252 (not < Pers., despite Räsänen; see TMN 1, 488).
VEWT 211, ЭСТЯ 4, 251, EDT 938 (with a highly dubious derivation from *jum- 'round').
VEWT 295.
EDT 293. Turk. bača-k 'fast' > WMong. bačag.
VEWT 273, ЭСТЯ 6, 27-29. The root seems archaic, but in most languages (beginning with OT) was substituted by the synonymous *Kod- (v. sub *k`ŏda), being preserved only in Chag., Osm. and Chuv.

VEWT 274, EDT 595-596, ЭСТЯ 6, 27-28, Федотов 2, 361. The original meaning (observable in most ancient occurrences, see EDT 595) must have been 'to put aside, leave, abandon'; the meaning 'put' appears somewhat later and is probably due to a merger with *Ko- 'to put' (v. sub \I*ga),\i not attested before the XIVth century.

CHG: quju, qujɨ (MA, Бор. Бад.), quji (Pav. C., Abush.)

REFERENCE: VEWT 103, EDT 418-419, Лексика 392.  Ogh. čel-tik > Pers.  čaltuk,  šaltūk (despite VEWT 104). Turk. čelpek > Pers. čalpak (TMN 3, 1111). The meaning 'eye pus, mucus' in *čel-pek developed under the influence of the similar *čapak (see under *čap- 'plaster'), but the two roots should be clearly distinguished (despite EDT 418).
Дыбо 322-323, Лексика 256. See ibid. a number of other forms, probably going back to the same stem, but restructured phonetically because of the root's expressive nature.

MEANING: 1 a k. of cloak 2 lap, skirt  3 used clothing 4 bedding under the saddle 5 woman's gown 6 gown 7 gusset (in clothes)
RUSMEAN: 1 род плаща 2 подол, фалда 3 старая, потертая одежда 4 подстилка под седло, чепрак 5 женский халат 6 халат 7 клин (в одежде)
CHG: čapan 1 (R; Pav. C. jamaɣlɨɣ čapan 'mended cloak'), čabuq 2 (Pav. C.), (OKypch.) čapɣut 3 (AH)
TRM: čabɨt 5, čapan 6, čapɨ 'ornamental trimming for clothes' lap'
KHAL: čabuɣ 'trimmed section on a woman's  tunic'
KRG: čabū 7; čapan 6, čapan-čapqɨt 'upper clothes', čopqut 'quilted coat under armour; expensive costume'
NOGX: šabuw 'gusset-like front part of gown's laps'
REFERENCE: VEWT 99, EDT 396, TMN 3, 47, Аникин 643. Several derivations are clearly distinguishable: a) *čap-gut 'upper clothes, garment' (with later development > 'used clothes'); b) *čap-rak 'bedding under the saddle'; c) *čap-an 'cloak, gown'; d) *čap-gu 'lap, gusset' - all clearly related to each other.

VEWT 105, EDT 399, Щербак 1961, 120. Cf. also Chag. čiber 'mountain goat' (R). The reflex -b- in Turkm. and Uygh. may be an indication of original vowel length (?) Shcherbak's hypothesis of the word being borrowed < Iranian is dubious; Pers. čapiš, čapuš itself may well be borrowed < Turkic. In any case, the Persian form cannot be a regular IE match for Lat. \Icaper.\i Cf. WH 1, 157, sub caper: Np. čapiš...lautlich unmöglich"; indeed
column36: Common Iranian  -p- (< IE -p-) > Mod. Pers. and NW-Iran. -b-
column37: in exceptional cases  -v- (Расторгуева ЗИФ 114-115); a parallel for  \Icaper\i may perhaps be found in Sak. cau̯
column40: Bailey 105). One should mention the problematic "Wanderformen" Rum. cap
column44: Slav. *cá́pъ 'he-goat'; cf. also Oyr. čāp 'one year-old roebuck' ( < Mong.?). See Трубачев 1960
column46: Orel 47 with literature; note especially Hubschmid's (1954
column47: 49) hypothesis of the Turkic origin of this Wanderwort."

MEANING: 1 to ask, require 2 to hire, lease 3 price 4 servant 5 envoy 6 to be satisfied 7 to give satisfaction

ATU: jalvar-, jalɨn- (OUygh.) 1, jalabač (Orkh., Yen.), jalavač (OUygh.) 5, jalčɨ-t- 7 (OUygh.)
CHG: jalbar- 1 (MA), jalɨn- 1 (Abush.), jal (Буд.) 3, jalavač (AH) 5, jalčɨ- 6, 7 (Ettuhf., Pav. C.)
ALT: jal, d́al 3, jalbar-, d́albar-, jalɨn-, d́alɨn- 1
REFERENCE: VEWT 181-183, EDT 920, 921, 922, 931, ЭСТЯ 4, 84-85, 89, 92-93, 102-103, 107; TMN 4, 108, Щербак 1997, 121 (Turk. jalbar- > Mong. ǯalbari-). The root is no doubt archaic, but presents some problems: the deriving simple stem *jāl is attested late, and there seems to be no vowel length in the derivatives *jalɨn-, *jal-bar- (although this may be a later secondary shortening). The peculiar suffixation in jalbar-, jalabač, jalabar caused some authors (see, e.g., Clauson in EDT) to suspect a loanword, but its source is unclear and the forms may as well be genuine (as are certainly the forms *jāl, *jalɨn-).
VEWT 210. Turk. > Mong. ǯoli- 'to ransom' (KW 476; Щербак 1997, 164: MMong. ǯolia, WMong. ǯoliɣ < Turk. juluɣ), whence Man. ǯoliɣan etc. (see ТМС 1, 263).
EDT 944, ЭСТЯ 4, 184-185. Turk. > WMong. ǯanči-, janči-, KW 466, Щербак 1997, 122. See also notes to *jān(u)- 'threaten'.

EDT 942, ЭСТЯ 4, 187, Лексика 576. Ramstedt's hypothesis of *jeŋ- being derived from *jeg- 'better, top' could be accepted, but the Ud. parallel diŋe- makes it questionable.  We prefer to regard -ŋ- here as the root consonant.
VEWT 200, ЭСТЯ 4, 282-283, Stachowski 125. Turk. > Hung. gyalom, see Gombocz 1912.

See also  Стеблин-Каменский 1982, 77, comparing the Sak. form with Pers., Tadzh. kalam 'cabbage' (> Turkm. kelem) - these all may be variously transformed substratum loanwords, cf. also Greek krambǟ 'cabbage, radish, rutabaga' - according to Frisk possibly < Pelasg.

SHR: šoqta- 'to besprinkle idols with an exclmation šoq!' R 4, 1024)
ALT: čoɣɨr- 2 (Lebed. R 3, 2014), čoqto- 'to besprinkle idols with an exclamation čoq!' (R 3, 2009)
REFERENCE: VEWT 113-114, Егоров 328, Федотов 2, 426-427. Räsänen's attempt to explain the verb as baptism through immersion" (linking Kypch. čoqur 'pit' and Taranchi čoqur- 'to sink' (R 3
column36: 2007) appears unconvincing. The former word is derived from čok- 'to delve'
column37: and the latter should be corrected to čökür- according to more modern sources. The semantic transfer of a pagan ceremony to the Christian one seems quite natural in an islamicized society.  The same root may be represented by the exclamation (made during a libation)
column40: and further - the approbatory exclamation Kirgh. čok!
column41: Kaz. šoq! etc. Quite unlikely is the hypothesis of a loan from Hebrew (Y. Malov
column43: the meaning in Chuv. ('pledge') and the external parallels suggest that the religious component in the meaning of *čok- is relatively late (having evolved after the separation of Bulgars): 'pledge' > 'sacrifice' > 'praying' > 'baptizing'. Turk. > Hung. csök 'sacrifice'

REFERENCE: ЭСТЯ 2, 107-108. Cf. perhaps also Yak. bet-tex (Dolg. bettek) 'here, closely', Yak., Dolg. beterē 'this, nearest side' (although it may go back to \I*bet\i 'face'; derivation < *be-rü 'this side' in ЭСТЯ 2, 124, followed by Stachowski 59, is hardly plausible). The sometimes proposed explanation as \I*bu\i ile, i.e.  together with it" or "by means of it" is not quite acceptable for semantic reasons. As for the Oghuz variants with a labialized vowels
column36: they may have an assimilative origin. But on the whole the attribution of the Turkic form is still dubious (although the semantic derivation "similar
column38: looks" seems to be quite common in Altaic)."

ЭСТЯ 4, 31-32. Also reflected is a form *josuk, *josak. Clauson (EDT 975) and Doerfer (TMN 1, 555-557) follow Ramstedt KW 219 and regard the Turkic forms as borrowed < Mong., which is somewhat dubious because of the peculiar phonology of Mong. josun (words with *jo- are extremely rare in Mong.). PT *josuk (*josak) also strengthens the thesis about the Turkic origin of Mong. josun; Doerfer's hypothesis that Tat. josuq, Oyr. jozaq etc. reflect a contamination of *jasak and *josun is not very plausible (*jasak has usually a quite different meaning 'impost, tax' etc.), and there is also a completely unexplained (as a Mongolism) form Oyr., Tel. jozor. All this makes us rather think of Turk. *josun > Mong. *josun > Manchu joso, Evk. joso etc. (ТМС 1, 347).

MEANING: 1 turf 2 stem, stalk 3 a k. of plant
REFERENCE: EDT 471, Федотов 1, 247. The OT word is questionable: an OT Hapax, but the second part (java) is also a plant root. Taɣna java was added to sour milk in order to colour it. Cf. Sak. ttuṃgara, Tokh. B tvāṇKārai, Tib. (Khotan) don-gra 'ginger'. Bailey derives from Iran. *tuvam-kara, i.e. 'made thick', but a Turkic origin (with Sak. suffixation) is also possible. If the Oyr. and Chuv. forms belong here the approximate PT reconstruction could be *Tagna 'root, stalk'. Turk. > Mong.: Khalkha tāna 'лук многокорешковый'.

MEANING: 1 large earthenware jar for storing flour 2 bin, crib for flour, grain
RUSMEAN: 1 большой глиняный сосуд для муки 2 ларь, закром для муки, зерна
KRG: kendik 'room for grain, fuel' (may be < Pers.)
REFERENCE: EDT 729. Clauson regards the word as an unequivocal iranism. The Iranian forms are: Pekhl. kndwg ( > Armen. k'andouk), Pers. kandū, kandūk 'big earthenware vessel for storing grain', Osset. xaendyg 'pail for pickled cheese'. Persian is the source of Syr. kndwk-, Arab. kandūǯ 'big vessel for grain'. Also related is Sak. khadīrakya (*xandīra-) 'a vessel' (possibly, some basket-work, see Bailey 71, Аб. 4, 173). Abayev derives the above forms from Iran. *kan- 'to dig' - which is not quite plausible (in a participle we would expect the zero grade vocalism; unclear is the labial vowel in the suffix; semantics raises doubts). On the other hand, all the above Iranian forms can be well explained as Turkisms, including the Saka form - with the suffix -rak (a wellknown suffix for receptacles, see Bang 1918). External parallels provide the final support for such a decision.   Middle Greek kóndü 'potǟ́rion' may be < Bulg., cf. the Chuv. semantics (see Фасмер sub кандия; cf. also other European words possibly having the same source).
